channel.title: Comments on: Silverlight Stopwatch class in C#

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/blog/index.php/archives/723/comment-page-1#comment-3018">claudio</a>.
@claudio: Whoops! Must have done a search/replace and managed to spell it wrong. Need to spell check my APIs! :) I've fixed the problem. Thanks for the heads-up!
item.content:encoded:
In reply to claudio.

@claudio: Whoops! Must have done a search/replace and managed to spell it wrong. Need to spell check my APIs! :) I’ve fixed the problem. Thanks for the heads-up!

item.title: By: claudio
item.dc:creator: claudio
item.description: Hi, This class will be used in my solution by files shared between Silverlight and .NET 4.0. So for compatibility issue, you should correct the word Ellapsed with Elapsed. It's just cosmetic, but it can produce compilation problem in case of shared code. Anyway Thanx -Claudio
item.content:encoded:
Hi,
This class will be used in my solution by files shared between Silverlight and .NET 4.0.
So for compatibility issue, you should correct the word Ellapsed with Elapsed. It’s just cosmetic, but it can produce compilation problem in case of shared code.
Anyway Thanx
-Claudio

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/blog/index.php/archives/723/comment-page-1#comment-2964">Vincent</a>.
I've updated the code, and tested it. Thanks all for the suggestions. Not sure why my tests worked when I wrote it.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Vincent.

I’ve updated the code, and tested it. Thanks all for the suggestions. Not sure why my tests worked when I wrote it.

item.title: By: Vincent
item.dc:creator: Vincent
item.content:encoded:
Fixed functions:

// Timespan expects the value indiciated as 100ns .. thats 1 / 10000 of a ms.
public TimeSpan Ellapsed
{
get { return new TimeSpan( GetCurrentElapsed() * 10000 ); }
}

// GetCurrentElapsed() returns the MS already, no need to adjust that
public long EllapsedMilliseconds
{
get { return GetCurrentElapsed(); }
}

// getting value in milliseconds, gotta recalculate to turn it into ticks
public long EllapsedTicks
{
get { return GetCurrentElapsed() * TimeSpan.TicksPerMillisecond; }
}

item.title: By: Vincent
item.dc:creator: Vincent
item.description:
There is a mistake. Has been said 3 times by now. this is the 4th. The fact you say the documentation leads you to think its correct, suggest you haven't tested it nor read the documentation correctly.
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.environment.tickcount.aspx
Clearly states it returns a value in milliseconds and not ticks.
Other then that, a big thanks for the code :) Works fine after some minor bug fixing
item.content:encoded:
There is a mistake. Has been said 3 times by now. this is the 4th. The fact you say the documentation leads you to think its correct, suggest you haven’t tested it nor read the documentation correctly.

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.environment.tickcount.aspx

Clearly states it returns a value in milliseconds and not ticks.

Other then that, a big thanks for the code :) Works fine after some minor bug fixing

item.title: By: Rui Fan
item.dc:creator: Rui Fan
item.description: Pospa and Chad Riddle are saying the samething. Environment.TickCount is the milliseconds. From MSDN: TickCount is different from the Ticks property, which is the number of 100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 1/1/0001, 12:00am.
item.content:encoded:
Pospa and Chad Riddle are saying the samething.
Environment.TickCount is the milliseconds.
From MSDN:
TickCount is different from the Ticks property, which is the number of 100-nanosecond intervals that have elapsed since 1/1/0001, 12:00am.

item.title: By: Sree
item.dc:creator: Sree

Thanks for the code. I could not make it work as is but Chad Riddle's comments worked for me.
Sree
item.content:encoded:

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.description: Popsa -- if that's the case, what would the right answer be? The documentation doesn't lead me to believe it's wrong, and that would be an inconsistency in the framework.
item.content:encoded: Popsa — if that’s the case, what would the right answer be? The documentation doesn’t lead me to believe it’s wrong, and that would be an inconsistency in the framework.

item.title: By: Pospa
item.dc:creator: Pospa
item.description: There is an error in this implementation. Because TimeSpan.TicksPerMillisecond in mos of cases does not corespondent with ticks/s used for Environment.TickCount computing. You should to review your code.
item.content:encoded: There is an error in this implementation. Because TimeSpan.TicksPerMillisecond in mos of cases does not corespondent with ticks/s used for Environment.TickCount computing. You should to review your code.
